trans-unit.source: Implements the basic functionality of a scroll bar control.
You typically do not inherit directly from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> class.
To create your own scroll bar class, inherit from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.VScrollBar> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HScrollBar> class.
The scroll box is sometimes referred to as the scroll thumb.
To adjust the value range of the scroll bar control, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Minimum%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Maximum%2A> properties.
To adjust the distance the scroll box moves, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> properties.
To adjust the starting point of the scroll box, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> property when the control is initially displayed.

User interface guidelines suggest that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> properties are set relative to the size of the view that the user sees, not to the total size including the unseen part.

For example, if you have a picture box with scroll bars displaying a large image, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> properties should be set relative to the size of the picture box, not to the size of the image.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar"></xref> class.
By default, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.TabStop%2A> property is set to `false` when a new instance of a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> is created.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar"></xref> is automatically resized to fit its contents.
Setting the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.AutoSize%2A> property has no effect on the appearance of the control.
`true` if the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar"></xref> should be automatically resized to fit its contents; otherwise, `false`.
Occurs when the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.AutoSize"></xref> property changes.
For more information about handling events, see [NIB: Consuming Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/01e4f1bc-e55e-413f-98c7-6588493e5f67).
Gets or sets the background color for the control.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Color"></xref> that represents the background color of the control.
The default is the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.DefaultBackColor"></xref> property.
Occurs when the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.BackColor"></xref> property changes.
Gets or sets the background image displayed in the control.
An <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref> that represents the image to display in the background of the control.
Occurs when the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.BackgroundImage"></xref> property changes.
Gets or sets the background image layout as defined in the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ImageLayout"></xref> enumeration.
One of the values of <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ImageLayout"></xref> (Center , None, Stretch, Tile, or Zoom).
Tile is the default value.
Occurs when the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.BackgroundImageLayout"></xref> property changes.
Occurs when the control is clicked if the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.StandardClick"></xref> bit flag is set to `true` in a derived class.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> control sets the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.StandardClick> bit flag to `false`, so the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> will not raise the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Click> event.
Gets the required creation parameters when the control handle is created.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.CreateParams"></xref> that contains the required creation parameters when the handle to the control is created.
Gets the default Input Method Editor (IME) mode supported by this control.
As implemented in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> class, this property always returns the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ImeMode?displayProperty=fullName> value.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ImeMode"></xref> values.
Gets the default distance between the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar"></xref> control edges and its contents.
<xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Padding.Empty"></xref> in all cases.
Occurs when the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar"></xref> control is double-clicked.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> control sets the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.StandardClick> bit flag to false, so the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> will not raise the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.DoubleClick> event.
Gets or sets the font of the text displayed by the control.
The <xref href="System.Drawing.Font"></xref> to apply to the text displayed by the control.
The default is the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.DefaultFont"></xref> property.
Occurs when the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Font"></xref> property changes.
Gets or sets the foreground color of the scroll bar control.
This property can only be changed programmatically; it is not visible in the Properties window.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Color"></xref> that represents the foreground color for this scroll bar control.
The default is the foreground color of the parent control.
Occurs when the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.ForeColor"></xref> property changes.
Returns the bounds to use when the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar"></xref> is scaled by a specified amount.
This is a helper method that used by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.ScaleControl%2A> method to return the bounds that the control should be scaled by.
You may override this method if you wish to reuse <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.ScaleControl%2A> scaling logic, but you need to supply your own bounds.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Rectangle"></xref> that specifies the initial bounds.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.SizeF"></xref> that indicates the amount the current bounds should be increased by.

A bitwise combination of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.BoundsSpecified"></xref> values that indicate the how to define the control's size and position returned by <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.GetScaledBounds(System.Drawing.Rectangle,System.Drawing.SizeF,System.Windows.Forms.BoundsSpecified)"></xref>.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Rectangle"></xref> specifying the scaled bounds.
Gets or sets the Input Method Editor (IME) mode supported by this control.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ImeMode"></xref> values.
Occurs when the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.ImeMode"></xref> property changes.
Gets or sets a value to be added to or subtracted from the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value"></xref> property when the scroll box is moved a large distance.

When the user clicks in the scroll bar track on either side of the scroll box, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> property changes according to the value set in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> property.
You can handle key press events so that when the user presses the PAGE UP or PAGE DOWN key the scroll box moves.

User interface guidelines suggest that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> properties are set relative to the size of the view that the user sees, not to the total size including the unseen part.

For example, if you have a picture box with scroll bars displaying a large image, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> properties should be set relative to the size of the picture box, not to the size of the image.
A numeric value.
The default value is 10.
The assigned value is less than 0.
Gets or sets the upper limit of values of the scrollable range.

You might consider adjusting the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Maximum%2A> property dynamically to match the size of the scroll bar's parent in proportion to pixel size or to the number of rows or lines displayed.
The maximum value can only be reached programmatically.
The value of a scroll bar cannot reach its maximum value through user interaction at run time.

The maximum value that can be reached through user interaction is equal to 1 plus the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Maximum%2A> property value minus the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> property value.
If necessary, you can set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Maximum%2A> property to the size of the object -1 to account for the term of 1.
A numeric value.
The default value is 100.
Gets or sets the lower limit of values of the scrollable range.
A numeric value.
The default value is 0.
Occurs when the user clicks the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar"></xref> control with the mouse.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> control does not raise the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.MouseClick> event.
Occurs when the user double-clicks the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar"></xref> control with the mouse.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> control does not raise the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.MouseDoubleClick> event.
Occurs when the mouse pointer is over the control and the user presses a mouse button.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> control does not raise the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.MouseDown> event.
Occurs when the user moves the mouse pointer over the control.
Occurs when the user moves the mouse pointer over the control and releases a mouse button.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> control does not raise the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.MouseUp> event.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.EnabledChanged"></xref> event.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.HandleCreated"></xref> event.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.MouseWheel"></xref> event
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> control will convert mouse wheel movements to scrolling when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> is in focus.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [NIB: Raising an Event](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/f2adaf01-1ed1-42e1-8c31-8d467e7e0ee2).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.OnMouseWheel%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs"></xref>
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Scroll"></xref> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [NIB: Raising an Event](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/f2adaf01-1ed1-42e1-8c31-8d467e7e0ee2).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.OnScroll%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.ValueChanged"></xref> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [NIB: Raising an Event](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/f2adaf01-1ed1-42e1-8c31-8d467e7e0ee2).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.OnValueChanged%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Occurs when the control is redrawn.
Occurs when the scroll box has been moved by either a mouse or keyboard action.
For more information about handling events, see [NIB: Consuming Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/01e4f1bc-e55e-413f-98c7-6588493e5f67).
Gets or sets the value to be added to or subtracted from the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value"></xref> property when the scroll box is moved a small distance.

When the user presses one of the arrow keys or clicks one of the scroll bar buttons, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> property changes according to the value set in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> property.

User interface guidelines suggest that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> properties are set relative to the size of the view that the user sees, not to the total size including the unseen part.

For example, if you have a picture box with scroll bars displaying a large image, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> properties should be set relative to the size of the picture box, not to the size of the image.
A numeric value.
The default value is 1.
The assigned value is less than 0.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the user can give the focus to the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar"></xref> control by using the TAB key.
When the user presses the TAB key, the input focus is set to the next control in the tab order.
Controls with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.TabStop%2A> property value of `false` are not included in the collection of controls in the tab order.
You can manipulate the tab order by setting the control's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.TabIndex%2A> property value.
`true` if the user can give the focus to the control by using the TAB key; otherwise, false.
The default is `false`.
Gets or sets the text associated with this control.
The text associated with this control.
Occurs when the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Text"></xref> property changes.
Returns a string that represents the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar"></xref> control.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.ToString%2A> method returns a string that includes the type and the values for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Minimum%2A><xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Minimum%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> properties.
A string that represents the current <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar"></xref>.
Updates the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar"></xref> control.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.UpdateScrollInfo%2A> method redraws the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar> by using the values of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Minimum%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Maximum%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value%2A> properties.
Gets or sets a numeric value that represents the current position of the scroll box on the scroll bar control.
A numeric value that is within the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Minimum"></xref> and <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Maximum"></xref> range.
The default value is 0.
The assigned value is less than the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Minimum"></xref> property value.
-or-
The assigned value is greater than the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Maximum"></xref> property value.
Occurs when the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Value"></xref> property is changed, either by a <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Scroll"></xref> event or programmatically.
For more information about handling events, see [NIB: Consuming Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/01e4f1bc-e55e-413f-98c7-6588493e5f67).
Overrides the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.WndProc(System.Windows.Forms.Message@)"></xref> method.
A Windows Message object.
